#  [Bug 1161](<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1161>)
Using Version: R 4.
I think the problem as outlined in the OP can be stated as: the labelling of
axes is incorrect when
a list is supplied to the x argument. The OP and subsequent discussion confuses
the possibility to
provide x, y and optionally z as members of a list, and the separate need for z
to be a matrix so as to
be able to properly ascribe the datapoints to points on the x, y plane. Such a
list is a valid
input to the function per the help page of the function. The original proposed
solution I believe
does not fully solve the labelling problem and I propose the following patch as
a preferable
solution and try to provide a rationale for my design choices. The patch
passes: make check-devel.
Any comments and suggestions would be appreciated to both the content and
manner of this report
(it's my first bug report).

## Recreating the problem
See the first example of a call to persp in the code in the following section
to see example of the problem.

## Proposed Solution
I handle the labels appropriately when lists are provided while
maintaining the other pre-patch program behaviour in the examples
below. ie throws errors in same situations and uses the list elements
or the explicitly provided data as the current release version with
labels that conform.

I have taken care not to trigger evaluation or setting of anything other than
x, xlab, ylab, and
zlab earlier than the orginal code and even for those specific variables only
for cases where the arguments
dictate using the changes to the code. Nothing else is touched prematurely so
as to reduce the
possibility of breaking someone's code.

The original function will accept a list in which there are partial matches for
"x" and "y" with
its names. My reading of the help page is that this may be unintentional.
Nevertheless, I use lower
case x, y, and z for exact matches and the uppercase letters for the partial
matches so both cases
are handled by the patch ablbeit providing a slight clue to the user of the
distinction.

The only case I am unhappy about is: persp(x = list(x=d1, y=d2, z=d3)) where I
would
like the labels to be, d1, d2, and d3, to correspond to the behaviour of
persp(d1,d2,d3) but for
reasons described in the end notes, this is not easy to achieve because the
list gets evaluated and the
names d1, d2, d3 are lost.

```
  ### lines to be added at the top of the persp function in persp.R
  if (is.list(x)){
    if ("x" %in% names(x)) xlab <- "x" else "X" # else triggered when instead
of x a pmatch for x is found
    if ("y" %in% names(x)) ylab <- "y" else "Y" # else triggered when instead
of y a pmatch for y is found
    if (missing(z)) { # only use z from list if it is missing
      if ("z" %in% names(x)) zlab <- "z" else if (!<http://is.na|is.na>(pmatch("z",
names(x)))) "Z"
    }
  }
  ### Tests I ran on the current release of R and on the build with the patch
  x <- seq(-10, 10, length.out = 30)
  y <- x
  f <- function(x, y) { r <- sqrt(x^2+y^2); 10 * sin(r)/r }
  z <- outer(x, y, f)
  x1 <- x; y1 <- y; z1 <- z
  data.list <- list(x=x,y=y,z=z)
  data.list.with.names <- list(x=x1, y=y1, z=z1) 
  malformed.list <- list(mx=x,my=y,mz=z)
  ### Tests I ran to determine what behaviour is in release and which I want to
match in all but the case of labels when list is used
  persp(data.list.with.names, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col =
"lightblue") # x label is list and Y and Z are the other labels
  persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col = "lightblue") # lower
case x, y, z labels in release

persp(x1,y1,z1, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col = "lightblue") # x1,
y1, z1 are labels
  persp(list(x=x,y=y,z=z), theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col =
"lightblue") # x label is  a list in release
  persp(list(x=x,y=y,z=z), z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col =
"lightblue") # x label is  a list and y label is y and z label is z
  persp(list(x=x),y, z=z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col =
"lightblue")  # throws error in release
  persp(list(x=x, y=y), z=z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col =
"lightblue") # x label is a list in release
  persp(data.list, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col = "lightblue") # x
label is data.list in release
  persp(list(x=x), y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col = "lightblue")
# throws error in release 
  persp(list(x=x), z=z, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col = "lightblue") 
# throws error in release
  persp(malformed.list, theta = 30, phi = 30, expand = 0.5, col = "lightblue")
# throws an error in release
```

### Relevant Notes on persp function
+ If z is missing and x is not a list then x is assumed to be z and x is
assigned its default
+ If z is missing and x is a list then z is taken from the list but if z is
provided it overrides
  the list
+ Providing none of x, y, z throws an error
+ if the list does not contain any variable beginning with x, y, or z an error
will be thrown. eg
  any name with the regex x.* will be acceptable for x and similarly y.* and
z.* correspond to y
  and z.
+ If x is found in the list then y must come from the list too otherwise an
error is thrown

### Notes on Solution
+ if an argument to a function is a list I cannot easily get at the names
within the list via the
  deparse1(substitute(arg)) idiom. I would like the following to work in an
analogous way to the
  x=x1 providing an x axis label of x1. This doesn't work for a list because it
has to be
  evaluated before substitution leading to a label comprised of all the values
as follows:
```
        if (is.list(x)){
        if ("x" %in% names(x)) xlab <- deparse1(substitute(x), x) # this will
not work as x is evaluated losing the names of assigned to x elements
        if ("y" %in% names(x)) ylab <- deparse1(substitute(y), x)
        # ...
    }
```

*[Bug 18668] New: ImageMagick missing heic driver (libheif)*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18668>

            Bug ID: 18668
           Summary: ImageMagick missing heic driver (libheif)
           Product: Rtools
           Version: 4.3
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Toolchain and libraries
          Assignee: <mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>
          Reporter: <mailto:jeroen@berkeley.edu|jeroen@berkeley.edu>

Building the magick package against ImageMagick from rtools43 we see:


```
> library(magick)
Linking to ImageMagick 7.1.1.25
Enabled features: cairo, freetype, ghostscript, lcms, raw, rsvg, webp
Disabled features: fontconfig, fftw, heic, pango, x11
```

HEIC is a format that is important to several users of magick, see for example: 

 - <https://github.com/ropensci/magick/issues/292>
 - <https://github.com/ropensci/magick/issues/377>

It is also enabled in ImageMagick on recent Linux distributions, as well as
homebrew, msys2 etc.

*[Bug 18669] New: librsvg version is very old*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18669>

            Bug ID: 18669
           Summary: librsvg version is very old
           Product: Rtools
           Version: 4.3
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Toolchain and libraries
          Assignee: <mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>
          Reporter: <mailto:jeroen@berkeley.edu|jeroen@berkeley.edu>

The version of librsvg that is currently included with rtools is 2.40.21. This
is a patched-up version of the 2.40 branch which was released over 10 years
ago. The number of changes and fixes since then has been enormous:
<https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/-/blob/main/NEWS>

It would be great if the library could be updated to a version that is a bit
more current. Debian is currently on 2.54 and Fedora/Homebrew/MSYS2 on 2.57.
The 'rsvg' and 'magick' Windows R packages are currently using a librsvg 2.57
build from msys2, which performs very well. It would be a big regression to go
back to the 2.40 version from rtools43.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18666>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks for the report. Looking at the code, (getline.c, lines 721-726), it
seems it was intentional. At least, it was intentional that getline would
finish with editing a line if DEL or Ctrl-D is pressed when there are no more
characters. Already R 4.0 would exit in that case, so it has been happening for
some time at least.

It seems easy to change - simply by deleting the condition, one gets instead a
beep in that case, a bit like when pressing backspace too many times.

Do you think we should do that?

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18670>

            Bug ID: 18670
           Summary: help("qr") wrong about length(qraux) when LAPACK =
                    TRUE
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Documentation
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>

`qr(x, tol, LAPACK = TRUE)` is a named list with element `qraux` of length
`min(dim(x))`, _not_ always of length `ncol(x)` as stated in `help("qr")`.  The
correct length is clearly documented [by
LAPACK](<https://github.com/Reference-LAPACK/lapack/blob/c6bc40164ace127bc308da37b135791a9ecb4667/SRC/dgeqp3.f#L85-L86>)
and we even see the following in `Lapack.c`:

    SEXP tau = PROTECT(allocVector(REALSXP, m < n ? m : n)); // qraux

(If I may point out another typo in `qr.Rd`: `s/qr.aty/qr.qty/` in the body of
`\source{}` ...)
